journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of clinical oncology : official journal of the American Society of Clinical Oncology

title-group.article-title: Longitudinal Results from the Nationwide Just ASK Initiative to Promote Routine Smoking Assessment in American College of Surgeons Accredited Cancer Programs

contrib-group.on-behalf-of: on behalf of the Just ASK Quality Improvement Task Force

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, College of Arts and Sciences, University of Kentucky
2Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center
4Department of Radiation Oncology, Medical University of South Carolina
6Department of Surgery, College of Medicine, University of Kentucky

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Jessica L. Burris, PhD, University of Kentucky, 171 Funkhouser Dr., Lexington, KY 40506-0044, USA, Fax: + 1 859-323-1979, jessica.burris@uky.edu

fn.p: Disclosure of Conflicts of Interest: The authors have no relevant conflicts of interest to disclose.

sec.title: Purpose.
sec.p: Persistent smoking following cancer diagnosis causes adverse outcomes while smoking cessation can improve survival. Thus, integration of smoking assessment and cessation assistance into routine cancer care is critical. Aiming for incremental practice change that could be sustained and built upon through future quality improvement projects, the American College of Surgeons initiated Just ASK in 2022 to increase implementation of smoking assessment among its accredited Cancer Programs. This manuscript describes outcomes from Just ASK.

sec.title: Methods.
sec.p: 762 programs enrolled in this cohort study, followed Plan Do Study Act methodology, and used local quality improvement teams to facilitate practice change. The primary outcome was the “ask rate” (i.e., patients asked/patients seen). Programs completed three surveys across the 1-year study (89.8% retention), answering questions about their program plus organizational readiness, implementation barriers, implementation strategies, and clinical practices related to assessing smoking among newly diagnosed cancer patients. Data analysis involved descriptive statistics and analysis of change over time (e.g., McNemar chi-squares).

sec.title: Results.
sec.p: Programs (53.1% community-based) tended to report moderate organizational readiness, multiple implementation barriers, and adoption of 4.63 ± 1.49 of eight possible implementation strategies (e.g., training staff/providers). Programs reported frequency of assessing smoking status, documenting it in the EHR, advising patients who smoke to quit, and documenting advice and treatment increased over time (all p<.001). The ask rate increased from baseline to mid to final survey (p <.01; 87.79% vs. 88.65% vs. 91.92%, respectively).

sec.title: Conclusion.
sec.p: Just ASK is the latest, and by far the largest, endeavor to improve assessment of cancer patients’ smoking status. Participants reported significant advances within a short time span and study results underscore the potential for national accreditation organizations to transform oncology practice.
